# What is big data?

![](img/bigdata_definition.jpg){width="300px"}

## The 3 "V" {.center}

**Volume:** Extremely large datasets with many observations and/or features

![](img/)

::::{.columns}

:::{.column width="%"}

**Before**

A few persons were manually taking measurements such as soil moisture

:::

:::{.column width="%"}

**Now**

Hundreds of thousands of soil sensors gather soil moisture data

:::

::::


## The 3 "V" {.center}

<font color="gray">- **Volume:** Extremely large datasets with many observations and/or features</font>

- **Variety:** Very diverse data types (e.g. images, text, numerical) and structures

![](img/)

## The 3 "V" {.center}

<font color="gray">- **Volume:** Extremely large datasets with many observations and/or features</font>

<font color="gray">- **Variety:** Very diverse data types (e.g. images, text, numerical) and structures</font>

- **Velocity:** Generated at high speed

![](img/)

## Why now? {.center}

Recent years have seen an explosion of computing power

- Large cloud [servers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Server_(computing))
- Faster internet connections
- Better [CPUs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_processing_unit)
- [GPUs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graphics_processing_unit), initially designed to accelerate computer graphics, proved well suited to run vast amounts of simple computations in parallel

GPUs' new usage in particular opened the door to deep neural networks

More processing power

![](img/cloud.jpg)

## Why has big data become so essential? {.center}

Big data opens up the doors of [machine learning](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Machine_learning)—a subfield of [artificial intelligence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence) that can be defined as computer programs whose performance at a task improves with experience

With [deep learning](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deep_learning), it allows artificial neural networks to:

- Calculate predictions
- Generate novel data (generative AI)

## The power of big data and AI {.center}

In typical computing, a programmer writes code that gives a computer detailed instructions of what to do

This works very well for a number of applications, but many tasks would require an impossible amount of code and resources

By feeding a very large amount of data to complex algorithms such as neural networks however, we can train them to become better and better at some tasks without explicitly programming how they should do so

## The power of big data and AI {.center}

:::{.example}

Example:

:::

If you wanted to write a program that can recognize a dog in any image in a traditional computer programming fashion, you would have to write code analyzing images pixel by pixel and taking into account any possible dog breed, type of image (picture, blurred picture, drawing, cartoon, schematics...), dog positions, weather the dog is wearing clothes, etc.

This is an impossibly large task: there just isn't enough computing resources in the universe to make this possible

## The power of big data and AI {.center}

:::{.example}

Example:

:::

Yet, as humans, we can easily learn to detect a dog in an image

We intuitively create some abstract dog-model that we can then apply to any particular case we are presented with

## The power of big data and AI {.center}

:::{.example}

Example:

:::

Big data and deep learning have recently made this possible for computers too: by feeding a very large number images with and without dogs with their accompanying label ("dog"/"no dog") to a neural network however, we can now train that model to recognize dogs in images that it has never seen

This is a totally different approach from traditional programming: we are not explicitly programming the model on how to do this. We create a model and the model trains from the data
